div.sent: The structural and functional unit of all living things is cell.
Each cell requires oxygen and nutrient for survival.
Besides, hormones are required for growth and development of the living body.
Different organic functions within the cell generate some waste products.
Just as the cells require oxygen, nutrients and hormones to function, the cells require to get rid of the waste products too.
The skin, lungs, and kidney excrete the waste products.
Hence, it is seen that conveyance is required among the different systems of the body.
This conveyance is done by the circulatory system in collaboration with other systems.
Blood, heart, arteries, veins, lymph and lymphatic altogether form the circulatory system.
Blood circulatory system or the cardiovascular system in humans comprises of the heart, blood, and blood vessels.
They transport oxygen and nutrients to organs and tissues throughout the body and carry away waste products.
Blood and its Components: When there is a cut or injury, the red coloured fluid that comes out of the body is the blood.
Blood is a specialised fluid connective tissue.
Plasma: About 55 percent of the blood is composed of a liquid known as plasma.
Plasma is usually light yellow in colour due to the proteins dissolved in it.
Plasma consists mainly of water, which is about 90 percent.
The blood cells are suspended in plasma.
Plasma also contains albumin, prothrombin, fibrinogen, globulin, glucose, fat globules, mineral salt, urea, sodium, potassium, iron, lead, hormone, antibody, carbondioxide and so on.
Serum is the clear yellowish fluid that remains as the liquid portion of blood after clotting has taken place.
Before clotting occurs, the liquid of the blood is called plasma.
Oxygen carrier: The haemoglobin in the erythrocytes acts as the vehicle that carries oxygen from the lungs to all parts of the body.
Carbon dioxide carrier: The carbon dioxide produced as a waste product by the cells is carried by the blood to the lungs.
Nutrient carrier: The digested food products are carried by the blood stream to all the cells of the body.
Red blood cells: The red blood cells form about 45 percent of the blood.
They are usually described as minute bi-concave disc.
It has no nucleus.
A red blood cell is composed predominantly of a protein, and an iron compound called haemoglobin.
Haemo globin gives the blood its red colour.
When the haemoglobin content of the red blood cell decreases, the condition is called anaemia.
Red blood cells are produced in the bone marrow and the life span of one cell is 120 days or 4 months.
White blood cells: They are bigger in size than the erythrocytes.
They vary in form and size, have nucleus, contain no haemoglobin, and are essentially colour less.
They are much less in number compared to the red blood cells.
The white blood cells are produced in the spleen and bone marrow.
Platelets: The smallest cell in the blood is the platelet, which is produced in the red bone marrow.
They vary in shape round, oval, spherical and are found in bunches.Platelets do not have nucleus.
They begin the process of coagulation, or forming a clot.
Body defence: The blood also contains substances, which protect the body against certain diseases.
The leukocytes are able to attack and destroy the micro-organisms that cause diseases.
Hence, they are the defence force of the body.
Body temperature: The flow of the blood helps keep the temperature of the body uniform.
Hormone carrier: The blood caries the secretions of the endocrine, or ductless glands.
Blood clotting: When there is haemorrhage, the platelets set in the clotting process and stop bleeding.
There are three kinds of blood vessels'arteries, capillaries, and veins.
Artery: An artery is a vessel that carries blood from the heart to all the parts of the body.
These are thick-walled vessels that do not collapse when empty, and do not have valves.
They usually carry oxygenated blood, except for pulmonary artery that carries deoxygenated blood to the lungs.
The capillary blood vessel is simply a tube lined by a single layer of cells, the endothelium, which facilitates the exchange of gases.
Veins: The blood vessels that carry the blood from the whole body to the heart are called the veins.
The capillaries gradually reunite and increase in size to form veins.
The veins are less thick-walled than the arteries and collapse when empty.
They have valves to allow the blood to flow towards the heart only.
They usually carry deoxygenated blood.
Only the pulmonary veins carry the oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
It is about the size of a closed fist.
The heart is made primarily of muscle tissue that contracts rhythmically to propel blood to all parts of the body.
A tough, double-layered membrane known as the each other when the heart beats.
The pericardium protects the heart from heat and pressure.
The human heart has four chambers.
The two upper chambers are the right and left atria, which receive blood from the whole body through the veins.
The two lower chambers are the right and left ventricles, which are the powerful pumping chambers.
They pump blood to the whole body through the arteries.
The right and left sides of the heart are separated from each other by a wall of tissue.
The atria are smaller in size than the ventricles.
Innermost lining of the heart is the endocardium which lines all the chambers of the heart.
Each side of the heart pumps blood through pericardium surrounds the heart.
The inner layer of the pericardium, known as the epicardium, rests directly on top of the heart muscle.
The outer layer of the pericardium is attached to the sternum and other structures in the chest cavity and helps hold the heart in place.
The right side of the heart pumps oxygen-poor blood to the lungs, while the left side of the heart pumps oxygen-rich blood to the body.
The atria are smaller in size than ventricles.
Circulation of Blood through Heart: Openings into the right atrium are two large veins, the superior vena cava, and the inferior vena cava.
These veins bring back blood from the whole of the body, except the lungs.
The right ventricle is separated from the right atrium by the tricuspid valve, which is formed of three triangular flaps or cusps.
The right ventricle has a much thicker wall than the right atrium.
Leading from the right ventricle is a large blood vessel known as the pulmonary artery, which carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.
The opening is guarded by the semi-lunar pulmonary valve that prevents blood from flowing back into the right ventricle.
Into the left atrium open the pulmonary veins, which brings oxygenated blood from the lungs.
It communicates with the left ventricle through the mitral or bicuspid valve, which allows the blood to flow from left atrium to left ventricle only.
The left ventricle is the thickest-walled cavity of the heart.
The largest artery in the arises from the left ventricle.
The opening is guarded by a semilunar aortic valve.
The opening of the veins that bring blood to the heart is not guarded by valves.
The alternate contraction and relaxation of the atria and ventricles of the heart propel the blood throughout the body.
As the heart relaxes, blood flows from the veins into the heart.
The blood from the superior and inferior venae cavae flow into the right atrium, and blood from the pulmonary veins into the left atrium.
When the atrium contracts they force the blood they receive into the ventricles through the tricuspid and mitral valves.
Then the ventricles contract.
This closes the tricuspid and mitral valves and forces the blood into the arteries.
The pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs where it gives off the carbon dioxide and receives oxygen to be oxygenated.
This oxygenated blood is then passed into the systemic circulation through the left ventricle and aorta.
In short, arteries carry blood from the heart to all parts of the body, and veins return the blood to the heart.
The oxygen from the blood is retained in the cells and carbon dioxide is passed to the blood at the cellular level.
This deoxygenated blood is then carried by the vanae cavae to the heart.
And the cycle goes on.
Rheumatic fever: Rheumatic fever is characterised by fever and pain, tenderness, redness, and swelling of the joints.
Rheumatic fever can cause inflammation of the heart and damage to the heart valves (endocarditis).
This strain on the heart muscle causes rheumatic heart disease, which though occurs in childhood may cause death in middle or later life.
As a result the person may be paralysed.
The patient may become unconscious.
The paralysed part becomes non-functional.
Some patients cannot talk.
Excitement and tension may cause the condition.
Coronary thrombosis: The artery that supplies blood to the heart is called the coronary artery.
Sometimes, there is deposition of lipid in the walls of the coronary artery, which hampers the blood supply to the heart.
Narrowing of the coronary artery decreases blood flow to the cardiac muscles.
This leads to pain in the chest.
The condition is called coronary thrombosis.
It may cause sudden death.
High blood pressure: Blood pressure is the pressure of circulating blood against the walls of the arteries.
Due to lipid deposition in the walls of the arteries the lumen is narrowed, which naturally leads to increased pressure in the arteries.
This condition is called high blood pressure or hypertension.
Problems arising due to high blood pressure: The arteries in the body gradually lose their elasticity and become stiff.
This may cause clotting of blood within the arteries.
Measures to prevent heart disease: A regulated lifestyle goes a long way to prevent heart disease.
Respiration is the process in which cells produce the energy they need to survive.
In cellular respiration, cells use oxygen to break down the sugar glucose to produce energy, carbon dioxide and water.
Energy is required for all metabolic processes.
Energy is stored in food.
Respiratory Organs: The organs that take part in the total process of respiration comprise the respiratory system.
Nose and Nostrils: The two nostrils are the external opening of the nose, which lead into the nasal fossae.
The nasal fossae open behind as a vertical slit on either side of the nasopharynx.
The two nasal fossae are separated from each other by a vertical septum.
The margins of the nostrils are usually lined with a number of stiff hairs that project across the openings.
The nasal fossae are lined by mucus.
The hairs together with the mucus serve to arrest the passage of foreign substances, such as dust and small insects, and thus protect the lungs.
Nasopharynx: The upper part of the pharynx behind the nasal cavity is the nasopharynx.
The air enters the pharynx through the nasopharynx.
Larynx: The pharynx continues down as two tubes.
The front tube has cartilaginous walls, and so is kept always open; this is the beginning of the windpipe, and is called the larynx.
Within the larynx, or voice box, are the vocal cords.
The vocal cords vibrate when air is passed between them, so the larynx is also called the voice box.
Trachea: Trachea is the part of the air passage between the larynx and bronchi.
It is formed of smooth muscles and several ring shaped cartilage.
Alveolus: After the trachea enters the thoracic cavity it divides into the right and left bronchus, which enter the right and left lung respectively.
Within the lungs each bronchus divides repeatedly and eventually narrow down to tubes called bronchioles.
These divide further into even narrower tubes, called alveolar ducts.
Each alveolar duct ends in a grape-like cluster of thin-walled sacs, called alveoli (singular: alveolus).
The alveoli are lined by a single layer of cells.
Lungs: Each lung is formed of bronchus, bronchioles, alveoli, artery, vein, capillaries, and so on.
The right and the left lungs are situated on either side of the heart within the chest or thoracic cavity.
The lung is covered by a two layered membrane, the pleura.
The right lung is slightly bigger than the left lung.
The lung is light pink coloured.
When the lungs expand, air enters the lung; and when it contracts air is expelled from the lung.
Below the lungs is the diaphragm that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.
The up and down movement of the diaphragm helps in respiration.
Inspiration: The lungs themselves have no muscle tissue.
Their movements are controlled by the rib cage and the diaphragm.
As a result of these changes, the chest cavity expands.
Because the lungs are attached to the chest cavity, they also expand and oxygen rich air flows into the lungs.
This oxygen passes into the blood.
Expiration: In expiration the muscles that lift the rib cage and lower the diaphragm relax.
As a result, the rib cage and the diaphragm return to their original positions, and the lung contract with them.
With each contraction of the lungs the air inside is forced out.
The air that is passed out contains carbon dioxide that diffuses into the alveolar air from the blood.
This exchange of gases occurs between the alveoli and capillaries within the lungs.
The process of breathing is generally divided into two phases, inspiration and expiration.
In inspiration, air is moved into the lungs.
In expiration, air is forced out of the lungs.
Internal respiration occurs in the mitochondria of the cells.
It is then carried by the red blood cells in the arteries to all parts of the body.
As the blood vessels reach an organ it again becomes capillaries.
Here, the oxygen is released from the oxyhaemoglobin, which diffuses first into the interstitial fluid and thence into the tissue cells.
In the blood, the carbon dioxide is transported in the form of bicarbonate to the lungs.
In the lungs the carbon dioxide is released from the bicarbonate and passed to the alveoli.
When the lungs contract, the alveolar air is passed out of the body.
Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is an infectious disease.
Anybody at anytime may be affected by the disease.
Cause: The disease is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a rod-shaped bacterium.
Symptoms of tuberculosis include coughing, chest pain, shortness of breath, loss of appetite, weight loss, abdominal pain, evening rise of fever, chills, and fatigue.
Pneumonia: In this condition there is infection and inflammation of the lung.
Excessive cold or respiratory tract infection may lead to pneumonia.
The condition is more common in children.
Cause: Pneumonia is usually caused by viruses or bacteria.
Commonly, the condition is caused by pneumococcus, a bacterium formally known as Streptococcus pneumonia.
Pleurisy: Inflammation of the pleura is pleurisy.
It may be caused by bacterial or viral infection, or as a sequel to some other disease.
When inflamed, pleural fluid collects between the two layers of pleura.
Prevention: The patient should follow the treatment as per physician's advice.
Bronchitis: This is an acute or chronic inflammation of the inner lining of any part of the bronchi and bronchial tubes.
Living in unhealthy conditions, inhaling dust polluted air, smoking cigarettes, and cold are some of the reasons that may cause bronchitis.
Cause: The disease is caused by bacterial or viral infection of the respiratory tract.
Asthma: Asthma is neither a contagious disease, nor is caused by any microbes.
But the patients are susceptible to respiratory infection.
Cause: Allergens, such as allergic food, smoke, and dust, when enters the respiratory tract may cause asthma.
In infants, common cold may cause symptoms of asthma.
Difference from other disease is that a seasonal variation is noted.
Symptoms of asthma increase in certain seasons round the year.
Smoking is one of the major causes of lung cancer.
Smokers are at increased risk of developing lung and lip cancer.
People who do not smoke themselves but inhale tobacco smoke (passive smokers) are also at increased risk of developing cancer.
Smoking is extremely harmful to bronchitis and asthma.
Children of parents who smoke may develop respiratory diseases.
Smoking not only cause diseases, it also increases economic insolvency in a family.
The body system that co-ordinates the functions of all other systems is called the nervous system.
It helps the body to respond to stimuli in order to keep harmony with the environments.
Humans are superior to all other beings because of the presence of a highly complex brain structure.
Brain is formed by nerve cells called neurone.
Neurone: The structural and functional unit of nervous system is the neurone.
A neurone is the longest cell in the body.
The neurone comprises of two parts: central cell body or soma, and branched treelike structures that extend from the soma.
Soma: The soma is the main part of the neurone.
Soma may be of different shapes, for example, round, oval, or star-shaped.
The soma is composed of cell membrane, cytoplasm and nucleus.
Branched treelike structures: Two different types of branched, treelike structures that extend from the soma are called dendrites and axon.
There is usually dendrite plasma membrane cell body only one axon per neurone, and is the longest part of the cell.
Dendrites are multiple in number, and are shorter in length.
Information from other neurones, in the form of electrical impulses, enters the dendrites at connection points called synapses.
The information flows from the dendrites to the soma, where it is processed.
The output signal, a train of impulses, is then sent down the axon to the synapses of other neurones.
Cerebrum: The cerebrum is the main part of the human brain.
Most highlevel brain functions take place in the cerebrum.
The grey matter covers an underlying mass of fibres or axons called the white matter.
The cerebrum regulates most of the functions of the body.
Cerebellum: It is located at the lower back of the cerebrum.
Its outer part is grey coloured and the inner part is white.
The cerebellum co-ordinates voluntary movements by fine-tuning command from the motor cortex in the cerebrum.
The cerebellum also maintains posture and balance by controlling muscle tone and sensing the position of the limbs.
Medulla oblongata: The long, stalk-like lowermost portion of the brain stem is called the medulla oblongata.
It makes a gradual transition into the spinal cord at the foramen magnum.
The medulla oblongata controls respiration, cardiovascular function, digestion, levels of alertness, and patterns of sleep.
Cranial nerves: There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves extending from the cerebrum and brain stem.
The names and functions of few of these nerves are stated below.
Olfactory nerve: This carries the stimuli of smell to the brain.
Optic nerve: This carries the visual stimuli from the retina of eyes to the brain.
Auditory nerve: This carries the hearing and body equilibrium stimuli from the ears to the brain.
